contentrichtext.text: '''Baron Davies''', of Llandinam in the [[Montgomeryshire|County of Montgomery]], is a title in the [[Peerage of the United Kingdom]]. It was created in 1932 for the [[Wales|Welsh]] businessman, [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] [[Member of Parliament]] and philanthropist, [[David Davies, 1st Baron Davies|David Davies]]. He was the grandson and namesake of the prominent industrialist [[David Davies (industrialist)|David Davies Llandinam]]. {{As of|2012}} the title is held by the first Baron’s grandson, the third Baron, who succeeded to the title in 1944 after his father was killed in the [[Second World War]]. ==Barons Davies (1932)== *[[David Davies, 1st Baron Davies]] (1880–1944) *David Davies, 2nd Baron Davies (16 January 1915–September 1944). Davies was the son of David Davies, 1st Baron Davies, by his first wife Amy, daughter of L. T. Penman. He married Ruth, daughter of Major William Marshall Dugdale, in 1939. They had two sons. Lord Davies fought in the [[Second World War]] as a major in the [[Royal Welch Fusiliers]] and was killed on the Western Front in September 1944, aged 29, only three months after succeeding his father in the barony. His three-year-old eldest son David inherited the barony.<ref>[http://yba.llgc.org.uk/en/s2-DAVI-DAV-1880.html Welsh Biography Online]</ref> *[[David Davies, 3rd Baron Davies]] (b. 1940) ==Notes== {{refimprove|date=February 2013}} {{reflist}} ==References== *Kidd, Charles, Williamson, David (editors).
